stages.description: Using place value counters on a seven-column mat (M, HTh, TTh, Th, H, T, O) and large-format 'millions strips' to build, partition and compare numbers to 10,000,000
stages.example_activity: Build 4,006,050 with counters: 4 millions, 0 hundred-thousands, 0 ten-thousands, 6 thousands, 0 hundreds, 5 tens, 0 ones. What is the value of the 6? (6,000). What role do the zeros play? Compare 4,006,050 and 4,060,050 — which column differs?
stages.transition_cue: Child reads and writes numbers to 10,000,000 including those with zero placeholders, identifying the value of every digit without counters

stages.description: Using place value charts, Gattegno charts and number lines to represent and compare numbers to 10,000,000, connecting to real-world contexts (populations, distances)
stages.example_activity: Write 7,450,300 in a place value chart. Mark it on a number line between 7,000,000 and 8,000,000. Use a Gattegno chart to build it by pointing. The population of London is about 8,800,000 — write this in words. Order five large numbers.
stages.transition_cue: Child works with any number to 10,000,000 on paper, partitioning flexibly and comparing column-by-column

stages.description: Working with numbers to 10,000,000 mentally: reading, writing, partitioning, comparing and applying in context
stages.example_activity: What is 100,000 more than 3,950,000? Partition 6,204,500 into millions and the rest. Order: 5,999,999; 6,000,001; 5,990,999. Write 'three million, forty thousand and seven' in numerals.
stages.transition_cue: Child handles any number to 10,000,000 with instant confidence, explaining place value patterns in the ones-thousands-millions grouping

stages.description: Using number lines at various scales (tens, thousands, millions, tenths) to locate numbers and determine which bounding multiple is nearer, for both whole numbers and decimals
stages.example_activity: Round 3,847,500 to the nearest million: place it between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 on a number line. Midpoint = 3,500,000. Since 3,847,500 > 3,500,000, round up to 4,000,000. Round 3.847 to 1 decimal place: between 3.8 and 3.9, closer to 3.8.
stages.transition_cue: Child rounds any number — whole or decimal — to any degree of accuracy without the number line, using the digit-checking rule

stages.description: Drawing number line segments for rounding decisions, recording rounding to multiple degrees of accuracy, and using rounding to estimate calculations
stages.example_activity: Round 4,567,890 to the nearest 10; 100; 1,000; 10,000; 100,000; 1,000,000. Round 12.345 to 2 d.p., 1 d.p., and the nearest whole number. Estimate: 4,872 × 23 ≈ 5,000 × 20 = 100,000.
stages.transition_cue: Child rounds to any degree of accuracy instantly and uses rounding to estimate answers before calculating

stages.description: Rounding any number to any specified accuracy mentally, selecting appropriate accuracy for context, and using rounding for estimation and reasonableness checking
stages.example_activity: Round 9,995,500 to the nearest 10,000. Round 0.0456 to 2 decimal places. Estimate 78.4 × 19.6. A newspaper says 'about 3 million people watched'. What range of actual viewers could this represent?
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the appropriate degree of rounding for any context and explains the range of values that round to a given number

stages.description: Using vertical number lines (thermometer models) and horizontal floor number lines extending well below zero to count, compare and calculate intervals involving negative numbers
stages.example_activity: The temperature is -7°C and rises by 12 degrees. Walk from -7 on the floor line: count 7 steps to 0, then 5 more to +5. New temperature: 5°C. What is the difference between -8 and +6? Count steps: 8 + 6 = 14.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates intervals across zero without the number line, explaining: 'I add the distance from the negative number to zero and from zero to the positive number'

stages.description: Drawing number lines to show calculations with negative numbers, recording intervals, and solving problems involving negative numbers in context on paper
stages.example_activity: Draw a number line. Mark -5 and +8. The interval is 13 (count: -5 to 0 = 5, 0 to 8 = 8, total 13). A submarine is at -120 m. It rises 75 m. Draw this on a vertical number line. New depth: -45 m. Order: -12, 5, -3, 0, -8, 7.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates with negative numbers on paper using the additive model and solves context problems without drawing

stages.description: Working with negative numbers mentally in all contexts: temperature, coordinates, bank balances, sea level, and abstract calculations
stages.example_activity: What is -15 + 23? What is 4 − 11? The temperature falls from 3°C to -9°C. How many degrees did it fall? A bank balance is -£45. After a deposit it is £120. How much was deposited?
stages.transition_cue: Child performs calculations with negative numbers mentally, selecting the most efficient strategy and applying in unfamiliar contexts

stages.description: Using place value counters to model the two partial products in long multiplication, physically demonstrating why the tens row is shifted left
stages.example_activity: Calculate 347 × 24. Build 347 × 4 with counters: 1,388. Build 347 × 20: that is 347 × 2 tens, so each counter shifts one column left. Result: 6,940. Combine: 1,388 + 6,940 = 8,328. Why does the second row start with a zero?
stages.transition_cue: Child explains the place value reasoning behind the zero placeholder and transitions to the written method without counters

stages.description: Using the grid method alongside the formal long multiplication layout to show correspondence of partial products, then practising the compact method
stages.example_activity: Grid for 2,463 × 37: 6 cells. Check each against the compact method. Long multiplication: row 1 = 2,463 × 7 = 17,241; row 2 = 2,463 × 30 = 73,890. Total: 91,131. Estimate: 2,500 × 40 = 100,000. Plausible?
stages.transition_cue: Child completes long multiplication using the compact method independently, correctly managing carries across both rows

stages.description: Performing long multiplication fluently for any 4-digit × 2-digit calculation, with estimation and checking, and applying within multi-step problems
stages.example_activity: Calculate 4,085 × 53. A school orders 1,250 exercise books at 47p each. How much in total? Estimate first, then calculate.
stages.transition_cue: Child completes any long multiplication fluently and applies it confidently within multi-step problems

stages.description: Using place value counters and sharing trays to model long division by a 2-digit divisor, building the 'estimate-multiply-subtract-bring down' cycle with physical grouping
resources: multiplication fact cards for the divisor
stages.example_activity: Divide 832 ÷ 26. First write multiples of 26: 26, 52, 78, 104, 130... How many 26s in 83? 3 (3×26=78). Remainder 5. Bring down 2: 52. How many 26s in 52? 2 (2×26=52). Answer: 32. Check: 32 × 26 = 832 ✓.
stages.transition_cue: Child follows the estimate-multiply-subtract-bring down cycle without counters, writing out the multiples of the divisor as a reference

stages.description: Recording long division using the formal layout on paper, with a table of divisor multiples alongside, and practising remainder interpretation
stages.example_activity: Calculate 4,752 ÷ 18. Write multiples of 18: 18, 36, 54, 72, 90, 108, 126, 144, 162, 180. Work through: 47÷18=2 r11, bring down 5: 115÷18=6 r7, bring down 2: 72÷18=4. Answer: 264. Check: 264×18=4,752 ✓. Now try 3,925 ÷ 15 and express the remainder as a fraction.
stages.transition_cue: Child completes long division with any 2-digit divisor on paper, interpreting remainders as whole numbers, fractions or decimals as context requires

stages.description: Performing long division fluently, selecting the remainder form appropriate to context, and applying within multi-step problems
stages.example_activity: Calculate 7,344 ÷ 24. A factory makes 5,000 biscuits. They are packed in boxes of 36. How many full boxes? How many biscuits left over? Divide £156.80 equally among 14 people.
stages.transition_cue: Child completes any long division fluently, writes a zero in the quotient when needed, and selects the correct remainder interpretation

stages.description: Using physical number cards and operation signs to build expressions, then rearranging with bracket cards to show how brackets change the order of calculation
stages.example_activity: Lay out cards: 3 + 4 × 5. Calculate left to right: 35. Now calculate with BODMAS: 4×5=20, 3+20=23. Which does the calculator give? (23.) Now add bracket cards: (3 + 4) × 5 = 35. Brackets change the order. Try: 20 − 8 ÷ 2. Without brackets: 16. With brackets: (20 − 8) ÷ 2 = 6.
stages.transition_cue: Child evaluates expressions with mixed operations using BODMAS without cards, explaining which operation is calculated first and why

stages.description: Annotating expressions on paper to show the order of evaluation, inserting brackets to make expressions equal given values, and using tree diagrams to show operation priority
stages.example_activity: Evaluate: 5 + 3 × 2 − 4. Annotate: first 3×2=6, then 5+6=11, then 11−4=7. Insert brackets to make: 5 + 3 × 2 − 4 = 12. Answer: 5 + 3 × (2 − 4) doesn't work... try (5 + 3) × 2 − 4 = 12 ✓. Draw a tree diagram for 2 + 3 × (4 − 1).
stages.transition_cue: Child evaluates any expression correctly using BODMAS and inserts brackets to achieve target values without trial and error

stages.description: Evaluating complex expressions mentally using BODMAS, creating expressions with brackets for given targets, and explaining why the convention is necessary
stages.example_activity: Evaluate: 6 × (3 + 5) − 12 ÷ 4. Make 24 using 1, 2, 3, 4 and any operations/brackets. Why do mathematicians need an agreed order of operations? If 8 + 2 × ? = 18, what is the missing number?
stages.transition_cue: Child applies BODMAS fluently in any expression and explains the convention clearly

stages.description: Using counters on Venn diagram hoops to find factors and common factors of pairs of numbers, and Cuisenaire rods to find common multiples by laying out sequences
stages.example_activity: Find factors of 48 and 36 using counters in Venn diagram hoops. Common factors: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12. HCF = 12. Lay out rods for multiples of 6 and 8: first to land on the same point is 24 (LCM). Is 47 prime? Check: no arrays other than 1×47.
stages.transition_cue: Child finds HCF and LCM systematically and tests primeness without physical materials

stages.description: Drawing Venn diagrams of factor sets, recording factor trees for prime factorisation, and using HCF/LCM to simplify fractions and find common denominators on paper
stages.example_activity: Draw a Venn diagram: factors of 60 and factors of 84. HCF = 12. Simplify 60/84 = 5/7. Draw factor trees: 60 = 2² × 3 × 5, 84 = 2² × 3 × 7. LCM = 2² × 3 × 5 × 7 = 420. Use LCM to add 1/60 + 1/84.
stages.transition_cue: Child finds HCF and LCM efficiently on paper and applies them to fraction operations

stages.description: Finding HCF, LCM and testing primeness mentally, and applying fluently in fraction simplification, common denominators and divisibility problems
stages.example_activity: HCF of 36 and 48? LCM of 12 and 18? Is 91 prime? (No: 91 = 7 × 13.) Simplify 72/96. Two buses leave at 8:00 a.m. Bus A runs every 12 mins, Bus B every 15 mins. When do they next leave together?
stages.transition_cue: Child applies HCF, LCM and prime factorisation fluently in any mathematical context

stages.description: Using fraction walls and fraction strips to simplify fractions by overlaying equivalent strips, and comparing fractions by finding common pieces
stages.example_activity: Simplify 8/12: overlay 8 twelfth-strips with larger strips until they match — 2 third-strips match. So 8/12 = 2/3. Compare 5/6 and 7/9: convert both to eighteenth-strips. 5/6 = 15/18, 7/9 = 14/18. So 5/6 > 7/9.
stages.transition_cue: Child simplifies by dividing numerator and denominator by HCF and compares using common denominators without strips

stages.description: Recording simplification steps on paper (dividing by common factors), converting to common denominators to compare, and ordering fractions including mixed numbers on number lines
stages.example_activity: Simplify 36/48: HCF = 12, so 36/48 = 3/4. Order: 2/3, 3/4, 5/8. Common denominator: 24. 2/3=16/24, 3/4=18/24, 5/8=15/24. Order: 5/8, 2/3, 3/4. Place 1 3/5 and 1 7/10 on a number line.
stages.transition_cue: Child simplifies to lowest terms in one step (using HCF) and compares fractions efficiently using the LCM as common denominator

stages.description: Simplifying and comparing fractions mentally, including mixed numbers and improper fractions, and selecting the most efficient common denominator
stages.example_activity: Simplify 84/96. Which is greater: 7/12 or 5/8? Order: 2 1/3, 2 3/8, 2 1/4. Is 11/15 more or less than 3/4? Explain without converting both.
stages.transition_cue: Child simplifies and compares any fractions mentally, sometimes using benchmark fractions (1/2, 1/4) for efficient comparison

stages.description: Using fraction strips to demonstrate adding and subtracting fractions with different denominators by converting to common-sized pieces first
stages.example_activity: Add 2/3 + 3/4. Convert to twelfths: 2/3 = 8/12, 3/4 = 9/12. Lay out 8 + 9 = 17 twelfth-strips. That is 17/12 = 1 5/12. Subtract 5/6 − 1/4: convert to twelfths. 5/6 = 10/12, 1/4 = 3/12. Remove 3: 7/12.
stages.transition_cue: Child finds common denominators and adds/subtracts without strips, converting to mixed numbers when results exceed 1

stages.description: Recording equivalent fraction conversions on paper, adding and subtracting mixed numbers using both the 'improper fraction' and 'separate whole/fraction' methods
stages.example_activity: Add 2 3/5 + 1 3/4. Method 1: convert to improper: 13/5 + 7/4 = 52/20 + 35/20 = 87/20 = 4 7/20. Method 2: whole parts 2+1=3, fractions 3/5+3/4 = 12/20+15/20 = 27/20 = 1 7/20. Total: 4 7/20. Subtract 3 1/4 − 1 3/4 (requires regrouping).
stages.transition_cue: Child adds and subtracts mixed number fractions on paper using either method, handling regrouping in subtraction

stages.description: Adding and subtracting fractions and mixed numbers with different denominators fluently, simplifying results
stages.example_activity: Calculate 5/6 + 7/8. 4 1/3 − 2 5/6. 3/7 + 2/5 + 1/10. A recipe needs 2 3/4 cups of flour. I have 1 1/3 cups. How much more do I need?
stages.transition_cue: Child performs any fraction addition or subtraction fluently, selecting the LCM and simplifying the result

stages.description: Using fraction circles and paper folding to show 'a fraction of a fraction' (multiplication) and sharing fraction pieces equally (division by a whole number)
stages.example_activity: Find 1/2 of 3/4: take 3 quarter-pieces, then halve the group — 1.5 quarter-pieces. But that is 3/8 of a whole. So 1/2 × 3/4 = 3/8. Divide 3/4 by 3: take 3 quarter-pieces and share into 3 groups — 1 quarter each. So 3/4 ÷ 3 = 1/4.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains why multiplying fractions gives a smaller result and why dividing a fraction by n multiplies the denominator by n

stages.description: Drawing area models (rectangles divided horizontally and vertically) to show fraction multiplication, and bar models for fraction division, recording the calculation alongside
stages.example_activity: Draw a rectangle. Divide it into 4 columns (quarters) and shade 3 (3/4). Divide into 3 rows (thirds) and shade 2 (2/3). The overlap = 6 out of 12 cells = 6/12 = 1/2. So 2/3 × 3/4 = 1/2. For 5/6 ÷ 2: draw a bar of 5/6, split into 2 equal parts: each is 5/12.
stages.transition_cue: Child multiplies fractions by multiplying numerators and denominators, cross-cancelling first, and divides by multiplying the denominator

stages.description: Multiplying and dividing fractions fluently, simplifying before multiplying when possible, and solving word problems involving fraction operations
stages.example_activity: Calculate 3/5 × 5/9. (Cross-cancel: 3/5 × 5/9 = 1/3.) Calculate 4/7 ÷ 2. A recipe uses 2/3 cup of sugar. I want to make 3/4 of the recipe. How much sugar? 2/3 × 3/4 = 1/2 cup.
stages.transition_cue: Child multiplies and divides fractions fluently, using cross-cancellation for efficiency, and applies in context

stages.description: Using hundredths grids, money and fraction-decimal-percentage matching cards to explore equivalences including eighths (0.125) and thirds (0.333...)
stages.example_activity: Shade 1/8 of a hundredths grid: that is 12.5 squares = 12.5% = 0.125. Use a calculator: 1 ÷ 3 = 0.333... This is a recurring decimal. Match cards: pair 3/8 with 37.5% and 0.375. Which is more: 0.6 or 58%?
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between fractions, decimals and percentages for all common values including eighths and recognises recurring decimals for thirds

stages.description: Completing FDP conversion tables, drawing percentage bar models, and placing fractions, decimals and percentages on a single number line
stages.example_activity: Complete: 1/8 = ? = ?%. 3/5 = ? = ?%. 0.35 = ? = ?%. Place 2/5, 0.45, 35% and 3/8 on the same number line. Which is largest? Use a percentage bar to find 35% of 240: 10%=24, 30%=72, 5%=12, total=84.
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between all three forms on paper and compares values expressed in different forms using a common representation

stages.description: Converting between fractions, decimals and percentages mentally, selecting the most useful form for any given problem
stages.example_activity: Which is greater: 7/12 or 60%? Convert 0.375 to a fraction in simplest form. Find 17.5% of 80. A shirt was £40 and is now £34. What percentage discount is that?
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the most efficient form for any calculation and converts fluently between all three representations

stages.description: Mixing paint, juice or recipe ingredients in given ratios, physically sharing objects into ratio groups using sorting trays, and using Cuisenaire rods to show proportional relationships
stages.example_activity: Share 20 counters in the ratio 3:2. Each 'part' = 20 ÷ 5 = 4 counters. Group A gets 3 × 4 = 12, Group B gets 2 × 4 = 8. Mix orange paint: 3 parts red to 1 part yellow. If I use 6 spoonfuls of red, how many yellow?
stages.transition_cue: Child finds the value of one part by dividing by the total number of parts and scales correctly without physical objects

stages.description: Drawing bar models to represent ratios, recording ratio tables showing scaling, and solving proportion problems on paper
stages.example_activity: Draw a bar model for sharing £150 in the ratio 2:3. Two bars and three bars = 5 bars total. Each bar = £30. Group A: £60, Group B: £90. A recipe for 4 people uses 300 g flour. Complete the ratio table for 6, 8, 10 people. Scale factor method: ×1.5 for 6 people = 450 g.
stages.transition_cue: Child solves ratio and proportion problems on paper using bar models or the unitary method, selecting the most efficient approach

stages.description: Solving ratio and proportion problems mentally, using the unitary method and scale factors, and distinguishing multiplicative from additive relationships
stages.example_activity: Share £240 in the ratio 5:3. A map scale is 1:50,000. Two towns are 4 cm apart on the map — what is the real distance? Is this additive or multiplicative: 'For every 3 red beads, there are 5 blue beads'?
stages.transition_cue: Child solves any ratio/proportion problem efficiently and always identifies whether a problem requires multiplicative or additive reasoning

stages.description: Using physical 'function machines' (boxes with input/output slots), mystery number envelopes, and concrete bar models where a letter card represents an unknown number of counters
stages.example_activity: A function machine does '× 3 then + 2'. Input 4: output 14. Input 7: output 23. Write the rule: output = 3 × input + 2. Using algebra: y = 3n + 2. Now: n + 5 = 12. Put counters in an envelope (n). The envelope plus 5 loose counters = 12 counters total. How many in the envelope?
stages.transition_cue: Child writes algebraic expressions from word descriptions and solves simple equations by reasoning about the unknown

stages.description: Drawing bar models to represent algebraic expressions and equations, using substitution tables to evaluate expressions for different values
stages.example_activity: Draw a bar model for 3n + 5 = 20. The bar has three 'n' sections plus a 5 section, totalling 20. So 3n = 15, n = 5. Evaluate 2a + b when a = 4, b = 3: 2(4) + 3 = 11. Complete a table of values for y = 2x − 1 when x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
stages.transition_cue: Child writes and evaluates algebraic expressions and solves one-step equations using bar models or inverse operations on paper

stages.description: Writing, evaluating and solving algebraic expressions and simple equations mentally, using formulae in context, and explaining that a letter represents a number
stages.example_activity: If n = 7, what is 4n − 3? Write an expression for 'a number doubled then reduced by 5': 2n − 5. Solve: 5x + 3 = 28. The perimeter of a rectangle is 2(l + w). If l = 8 and P = 26, what is w?
stages.transition_cue: Child uses algebraic notation fluently, evaluates expressions by substitution, and solves simple equations using inverse operations

stages.description: Building linear patterns with physical objects (tiles, matchsticks, cubes) and recording the number in each term, then finding all integer pairs that satisfy two-variable equations using counters
stages.example_activity: Build a tile pattern: term 1 = 3 tiles, term 2 = 5 tiles, term 3 = 7 tiles. What is the pattern? (+2 each time.) Predict term 10: 3 + 9×2 = 21. For a + b = 8: use red (a) and blue (b) counters. Find all pairs: (0,8), (1,7), (2,6)... (8,0). How many solutions?
stages.transition_cue: Child describes the common difference, predicts any term, and enumerates all positive integer solutions of a two-variable equation systematically

stages.description: Drawing pattern sequences and recording in tables, writing the term-to-term rule, and plotting solution pairs of two-variable equations on a coordinate grid
stages.example_activity: Draw the first 5 terms of a matchstick square pattern. Record: 4, 7, 10, 13, 16. Common difference: 3. Term-to-term rule: add 3. For 2x + y = 10: make a table of solutions. Plot on a grid: (0,10), (1,8), (2,6), (3,4), (4,2), (5,0). What do you notice? (They lie on a straight line.)
stages.transition_cue: Child generates sequences from rules and enumerates solutions on a coordinate grid, noticing the linear pattern

stages.description: Working with sequences and two-variable equations abstractly: finding the nth term rule (informally), predicting terms, and finding all solutions within a range
stages.example_activity: A sequence starts 5, 9, 13, 17... What is the 20th term? Write a rule. Find all positive integer pairs (a, b) where 3a + 2b = 18. How many solutions does x + y = 100 have if both must be positive?
stages.transition_cue: Child finds any term of a linear sequence and systematically enumerates solutions to two-variable equations

stages.description: Cutting parallelograms from card and rearranging the triangle piece to form a rectangle, and demonstrating that two identical triangles form a parallelogram
stages.example_activity: Cut a parallelogram along the perpendicular height. Slide the triangle to the other end: it makes a rectangle. Area of rectangle = base × height. So area of parallelogram = base × height too. Take two identical triangles: put them together to form a parallelogram. Area of triangle = half the parallelogram = ½ × base × height.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains why A = b × h for parallelograms and A = ½ × b × h for triangles, identifying the perpendicular height (not the slant side)

stages.description: Drawing triangles and parallelograms on squared paper, identifying base and perpendicular height, calculating area using the formulae, and comparing with counted squares
stages.example_activity: Draw a parallelogram on squared paper: base 6 cm, height 4 cm. Count squares inside: about 24. Formula: 6 × 4 = 24 cm² ✓. Draw a triangle: base 8 cm, height 5 cm. Formula: ½ × 8 × 5 = 20 cm². Count squares to check. Identify the perpendicular height in a tilted triangle.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates areas of triangles and parallelograms from labelled diagrams, always using perpendicular height

stages.description: Calculating areas of triangles and parallelograms from given dimensions without drawing, including compound shapes, and working backwards from area to find missing dimensions
stages.example_activity: A triangle has base 12 cm and height 9 cm. What is its area? A parallelogram has area 56 cm² and base 8 cm. What is its height? Find the area of a shape made of a rectangle (10 × 6) with a triangle (base 10, height 4) on top.
stages.transition_cue: Child applies area formulae to any triangle or parallelogram and decomposes compound shapes, working forwards and backwards

stages.description: Building cubes and cuboids from 1 cm³ linking cubes, counting layers to verify the volume formula, and comparing volumes of different constructions
stages.example_activity: Build a 4 × 3 × 5 cuboid. Count: base layer has 4 × 3 = 12 cubes. Five layers = 60 cubes = 60 cm³. Verify: V = 4 × 3 × 5 = 60 ✓. Build a cube with edge 4 cm: V = 4 × 4 × 4 = 64 cm³. Which holds more: 5×3×4 or 6×2×5?
stages.transition_cue: Child predicts volumes before building and explains the formula as 'base area × number of layers'

stages.description: Drawing labelled cuboids on isometric paper, calculating volumes using the formula, and solving problems involving capacity (1 litre = 1000 cm³)
stages.example_activity: Draw a cuboid 8 cm × 5 cm × 3 cm. V = 120 cm³. A fish tank is 60 cm × 30 cm × 40 cm. V = 72,000 cm³ = 72 litres. What is the area of the base? (1,800 cm².) Compare area (cm²) with volume (cm³).
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates volumes from diagrams, converts between cm³ and litres, and distinguishes volume from area

stages.description: Calculating volumes from given dimensions, finding missing dimensions from volume, and solving real-world capacity problems
stages.example_activity: A cube has volume 125 cm³. What is its edge length? A box is 25 cm × 20 cm × h. Its volume is 5,000 cm³. What is h? How many 1-litre cartons fit in a 50 cm × 40 cm × 30 cm box?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates any cuboid volume and works backwards from volume to find missing dimensions

stages.description: Tearing corners from paper triangles and quadrilaterals to verify angle sums, measuring angles in regular polygons with a protractor, and using angle fans to show vertically opposite angles
resources: angle fan (two strips pinned at a point)
stages.example_activity: Tear corners off a quadrilateral. Arrange at a point: they complete a full turn = 360°. Open the angle fan: two lines cross, creating 4 angles. Measure opposite pairs: they are equal (vertically opposite). Measure all interior angles of a regular hexagon: each is 120°. Total: 720°.
stages.transition_cue: Child states angle facts for straight lines, points, triangles, quadrilaterals and vertically opposite angles, and applies them to find missing angles

stages.description: Annotating diagrams with known angles and angle facts, writing equations to find unknowns, and calculating interior angles of regular polygons on paper
stages.example_activity: In a triangle: angles are 48° and 67°. Third angle = 180° − 48° − 67° = 65°. Two lines cross: one angle is 72°. Label all four angles (72°, 108°, 72°, 108°). A regular pentagon: total interior = (5−2)×180° = 540°. Each angle = 108°.
stages.transition_cue: Child applies the correct angle fact at each step, labelling diagrams systematically and writing the justification

stages.description: Solving multi-step angle problems combining multiple angle facts, finding interior angles of any regular polygon, and reasoning deductively about angle relationships
stages.example_activity: Three angles at a point are 85°, 130° and x. Find x. In an isosceles triangle, the angle between the equal sides is 40°. What are the base angles? Find each interior angle of a regular octagon. Two straight lines cross and one angle is 3x − 10°. Find x if the vertically opposite angle is 2x + 20°.
stages.transition_cue: Child solves any angle problem by identifying and applying the correct facts, including setting up and solving equations

stages.description: Drawing circles with a compass, measuring radius and diameter of circular objects with a ruler, and identifying parts of a circle on physical objects (plates, wheels, clock faces)
stages.example_activity: Draw a circle with radius 5 cm using a compass. Measure the diameter: 10 cm. So d = 2r. Wrap string around a plate to find its circumference: about 3.14 times the diameter. Label centre, radius, diameter, circumference on the drawing.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws circles to specification and applies d = 2r fluently, naming all parts correctly

stages.description: Drawing and labelling circles on paper, calculating radius from diameter and vice versa, and investigating the circumference-to-diameter ratio
stages.example_activity: Draw circles with radii 3 cm, 4.5 cm and 6 cm. For each, measure the diameter and calculate C/d by wrapping string. Record: always approximately 3.14 (π). Label: radius, diameter, circumference, chord, arc. A circle has diameter 14 cm — what is its radius?
stages.transition_cue: Child labels all parts of a circle accurately and converts between radius and diameter without visual aids

stages.description: Working with circle properties abstractly: calculating radius, diameter and simple circumference problems, and reasoning about circle geometry
stages.example_activity: A wheel has radius 35 cm. What is its diameter? The diameter of a circular pond is 8 m. What is its radius? If C ≈ 3.14 × d, estimate the circumference of a circle with diameter 10 cm. A semicircle has diameter 12 cm — what is the length of the curved part?
stages.transition_cue: Child applies circle properties fluently and estimates circumference using π ≈ 3.14

stages.description: Plotting points on a large floor grid extending into all four quadrants, placing figures at negative and positive coordinate positions
stages.example_activity: Stand at the origin (0,0). Move 3 right and 2 up: (3,2) — quadrant I. Move 4 left and 1 up: (-4,1) — quadrant II. Move 2 left and 3 down: (-2,-3) — quadrant III. Move 5 right and 1 down: (5,-1) — quadrant IV. What are the sign patterns?
stages.transition_cue: Child plots points in all four quadrants and states the sign pattern: (+,+), (-,+), (-,-), (+,-)

stages.description: Plotting coordinates on paper grids in all four quadrants, drawing shapes from coordinates, and describing the quadrant of each point
stages.example_activity: Plot: (3,-2), (-4,1), (-3,-5), (0,4). Label each with its quadrant. Plot the vertices (-2,3), (4,3), (4,-1), (-2,-1). Join them. What shape? (Rectangle.) What are the coordinates of its centre?
stages.transition_cue: Child plots and reads coordinates in all four quadrants accurately on paper

stages.description: Working with four-quadrant coordinates mentally: identifying quadrants from coordinate signs, predicting midpoints, and describing coordinate patterns
stages.example_activity: What quadrant is (-5, 3) in? A square has vertices at (2,2), (2,-2), (-2,-2) and (-2,2). What is the length of each side? What is the midpoint of the line from (-4,6) to (2,-2)?
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies quadrants, calculates midpoints and describes coordinate patterns without a grid

stages.description: Building pie charts from data using fraction circles, rotating sector pieces to represent proportions, and reading pre-made pie charts by measuring sector angles with a protractor
stages.example_activity: 36 pupils were surveyed about favourite pets: dog=12, cat=9, fish=6, other=9. Each pupil = 360°÷36 = 10°. Dog: 12×10°=120°. Lay out the sector pieces. Read a pre-made pie chart: measure the 'walk to school' sector. If total = 120, and angle = 90°, how many walk? 90/360 × 120 = 30.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates sector angles from data and reads values from pie charts using the proportion method

stages.description: Constructing pie charts on paper using a protractor, calculating sector angles, and interpreting pie charts by reading angles and converting to frequencies
stages.example_activity: Data: Red=15, Blue=10, Green=5, Yellow=10. Total=40. Angles: Red=15/40×360°=135°, Blue=90°, Green=45°, Yellow=90°. Draw a circle, measure each sector. To read: a sector of 72° in a pie chart with total 200 represents 72/360×200=40.
stages.transition_cue: Child constructs and interprets pie charts on paper, converting between angles, fractions, percentages and frequencies

stages.description: Interpreting pie charts from descriptions or partial data, comparing two pie charts, and evaluating when pie charts are appropriate
stages.example_activity: A pie chart shows 25% travel by bus. If 80 people were surveyed, how many take the bus? Two classes each made a pie chart of favourite subjects. Class A has 30 pupils, Class B has 20. Can you compare them directly? Explain. When would a bar chart be better than a pie chart?
stages.transition_cue: Child interprets and constructs pie charts mentally and reasons about when they are the appropriate representation

stages.description: Using linking cubes to build towers of different heights representing data values, then levelling them (sharing cubes equally) to find the mean physically
stages.example_activity: Test scores: 4, 7, 3, 9, 7. Build 5 towers of these heights. Total cubes: 30. Level them: redistribute equally. Each tower = 30 ÷ 5 = 6 cubes. The mean is 6. The mean is the 'fair share' — what each person would have if everything were shared equally.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains the mean as the 'levelled' or 'fair share' value and calculates it by adding all values and dividing by the count

stages.description: Drawing bar representations of data sets, showing the levelling process, and recording the sum-and-divide calculation alongside
stages.example_activity: Data: 8, 5, 12, 3, 7. Draw bars on squared paper. Sum = 35. Count = 5. Mean = 35 ÷ 5 = 7. Draw a horizontal line at 7 to show the mean. Now reverse: the mean of 4 values is 9. Three values are 7, 11, 8. What is the fourth? (Total = 36, missing = 36 − 26 = 10.)
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates the mean from any data set on paper and works backwards from a given mean to find a missing value

stages.description: Calculating the mean mentally or with minimal jottings, finding missing values given the mean, and using the mean to compare data sets
stages.example_activity: Find the mean of 15, 23, 18, 20, 24. The mean height of 6 plants is 14 cm. Five plants measure 12, 15, 11, 16, 13. How tall is the sixth? Team A's mean score is 7.2 and Team B's is 6.8. Which team performed better on average?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates means, finds missing values and compares data sets using the mean fluently

stages.description: Handling and examining 3-D shapes, counting faces/edges/vertices systematically, and cutting out nets from squared paper to fold into 3-D shapes
resources: 3-D shape models (cube, cuboid, triangular prism, square-based pyramid, cylinder, cone)
stages.example_activity: Pick up a triangular prism. Count: 5 faces (2 triangles + 3 rectangles), 9 edges, 6 vertices. Cut out a net for a cube from squared paper (6 connected squares). Fold it to check it works. Try a different arrangement of 6 squares — does every arrangement fold into a cube? (No.)
stages.transition_cue: Child lists properties of common 3-D shapes from memory and predicts whether a given net will fold correctly before testing

stages.description: Drawing nets for common 3-D shapes on squared paper, completing property tables, and sketching 3-D shapes using oblique drawing
stages.example_activity: Draw the net of a square-based pyramid: a square with 4 triangles attached. Complete a table: shape, faces, edges, vertices for 6 shapes. Sketch a triangular prism on isometric paper. Which of these 4 nets fold to make a cuboid? Test by tracing and folding.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws nets and sketches 3-D shapes accurately, and predicts net validity by mental folding

stages.description: Identifying 3-D shapes from property descriptions, predicting net shapes mentally, and reasoning about relationships between faces, edges and vertices
stages.example_activity: I have 5 vertices and 8 edges. What am I? (Square-based pyramid.) How many different nets can a cube have? (11.) If a prism has a pentagonal cross-section, how many faces, edges and vertices? Can you spot a pattern linking F, E and V?
stages.transition_cue: Child reasons about 3-D shape properties from descriptions alone and uses spatial reasoning to evaluate nets mentally

stages.description: Using tracing paper and mirrors on coordinate grids to reflect shapes, and physically sliding shape cutouts to translate them, recording new coordinates
stages.example_activity: Place a triangle at (1,2), (3,2), (2,5) on the grid. Reflect in the y-axis using tracing paper: new vertices (-1,2), (-3,2), (-2,5). Slide the shape 4 right and 3 down: new vertices (5,-1), (7,-1), (6,2). Check: the shape hasn't changed size or shape.
stages.transition_cue: Child predicts new coordinates after reflection or translation before checking with tracing paper

stages.description: Drawing reflections and translations on coordinate grids, applying the coordinate rules (reflection in y-axis: negate x; in x-axis: negate y), and combining transformations
stages.example_activity: Reflect (3,4), (5,4), (5,7), (3,7) in the y-axis: (-3,4), (-5,4), (-5,7), (-3,7). Draw both shapes. Translate the reflected shape by (+2, -3). Final vertices: (-1,1), (-3,1), (-3,4), (-1,4). Describe the combined effect as a single transformation.
stages.transition_cue: Child applies reflection and translation rules to coordinates, drawing both object and image, and describes combined transformations

stages.description: Performing reflections and translations by calculating new coordinates mentally, combining transformations, and reasoning about which properties change and which are preserved
stages.example_activity: Reflect (-2,5) in the x-axis. Translate (4,-3) by (-7,+6). A shape at (1,1), (4,1), (4,3) is reflected in the y-axis then translated (+3,0). Where are the final vertices? Does reflection change the orientation? Does translation?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates transformed coordinates mentally and explains which properties are preserved by each transformation type

stages.description: Measuring angles in complex diagrams with a protractor to verify angle facts, then using the facts to calculate unknown angles step-by-step with physical reference cards for each fact
stages.example_activity: In a diagram: two lines cross. Measure one angle: 72°. Use the fact card 'vertically opposite angles are equal': opposite angle = 72°. Use 'angles on a straight line = 180°': adjacent angle = 108°. Verify with the protractor. Now solve without measuring: given one angle, find all others.
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the correct angle fact for each step and chains multiple facts together to find unknown angles, stating the fact used at each step

stages.description: Annotating complex angle diagrams on paper with known angles and fact labels, writing the chain of reasoning as equations
stages.example_activity: In a triangle: angle A = 55°. Angle B is on a straight line with an exterior angle of 130°, so B = 180° − 130° = 50° (angles on a straight line). Angle C = 180° − 55° − 50° = 75° (angles in a triangle). Write the reasoning chain clearly. Now: find x if 3x + 2x + 40° = 180° (triangle).
stages.transition_cue: Child writes systematic geometric reasoning for multi-step angle problems, including algebraic setups

stages.description: Solving complex multi-step angle problems by selecting and combining angle facts, including algebraic angle problems, without diagrams
stages.example_activity: Two angles on a straight line are (2x + 10)° and (3x − 15)°. Find x. An isosceles triangle has one angle of 34°. What are the other two? (Two cases: 34°, 73°, 73° or 34°, 34°, 112°.) Three angles at a point are 2y°, 3y° and 4y°. Find y.
stages.transition_cue: Child solves any multi-step angle problem by identifying the relevant facts, setting up equations, and presenting a clear chain of reasoning

stages.description: Conducting simple experiments (dice, coins, spinners, coloured counters in a bag), recording outcomes, and placing events on a physical probability line from 'impossible' to 'certain'
stages.example_activity: Roll a die 30 times. Tally each number. Are all outcomes roughly equal? Place event cards on the probability line: 'rolling a 7' (impossible), 'rolling an even number' (even chance), 'rolling less than 7' (certain). What fraction of outcomes are 'rolling a 3'? 1/6.
stages.transition_cue: Child lists all equally likely outcomes and expresses probability as a fraction (favourable outcomes / total outcomes)

stages.description: Drawing sample space diagrams and tables to list all outcomes, recording probabilities as fractions on a number line from 0 to 1
stages.example_activity: Two coins are tossed. Sample space: HH, HT, TH, TT. P(two heads) = 1/4. Draw a probability number line: mark 0 (impossible), 1/4, 1/2, 3/4, 1 (certain). Place events: P(at least one head) = 3/4. A bag has 3 red, 2 blue, 5 green. P(red) = 3/10. P(not green) = 5/10 = 1/2.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws sample spaces systematically and expresses any simple probability as a fraction, placing it on the 0-1 scale

stages.description: Calculating simple probabilities mentally, comparing probabilities expressed as fractions, and reasoning about fairness and equally likely outcomes
stages.example_activity: A spinner has 8 equal sections: 3 red, 2 blue, 2 green, 1 yellow. P(blue)? P(not red)? Is it fair if you win on red and lose on everything else? (No: P(red) = 3/8 < 1/2.) Two events have probabilities 2/5 and 3/8. Which is more likely?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates and compares probabilities fluently and reasons about fairness and likelihood

stages.description: Creating physical data displays (cube tower charts, dot plots with counters) for two data sets side by side, physically comparing spread and central tendency
stages.example_activity: Class A test scores: 5,6,7,7,8,8,8,9,10. Class B: 3,4,6,7,8,9,10,10,10. Build cube towers for each. Which class has scores more bunched together? Which has a wider spread? Calculate the range of each: A = 5, B = 7. Which mean is higher?
stages.transition_cue: Child compares data sets by discussing both the typical value (mean) and the spread (range), using concrete representations

stages.description: Drawing back-to-back dot plots or bar charts, calculating range and mean for each data set, and writing comparative statements
stages.example_activity: Draw dot plots for two data sets side by side. Calculate: Mean A = 7.6, Range A = 5. Mean B = 7.4, Range B = 7. Write: 'On average, Class A scored slightly higher (mean 7.6 vs 7.4). However, Class B's scores were more spread out (range 7 vs 5), meaning their results were less consistent.'
stages.transition_cue: Child writes comparative statements using both mean and range, explaining what each measure tells us about the data

stages.description: Comparing data sets using mean, range and other summary statistics without drawing, identifying outliers, and evaluating which average is most representative
stages.example_activity: Team A: mean = 12.4, range = 8. Team B: mean = 11.8, range = 3. Which team is more consistent? Which has a higher typical score? A data set has values 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5, 20. Is the mean representative? What might be better?
stages.transition_cue: Child compares data sets using summary statistics and reasons about which average best represents the data in context

stages.description: Using physical data cards that pupils sort into order to find the median (middle card), and grouping identical values to find the mode (largest group)
stages.example_activity: Data: 4, 7, 2, 9, 7, 3, 7, 5, 8. Sort cards in order: 2,3,4,5,7,7,7,8,9. Middle card (5th of 9): 7. Median = 7. Group identical values: 7 appears 3 times (most). Mode = 7. Mean = 52÷9 ≈ 5.8. All three averages are different!
stages.transition_cue: Child finds median (by ordering and locating the middle), mode (by counting frequencies) and mean (by summing and dividing), and explains when each is useful

stages.description: Recording ordered data sets on paper, finding median and mode, and comparing all three averages in tables
stages.example_activity: Data: 12, 15, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25. Median = 18 (middle of 7 values). Mode = 15 (appears twice). Mean = 127÷7 ≈ 18.1. Which average best represents this data? Now try: 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 5, 100. Mean = 16.9, Median = 3, Mode = 3. The mean is pulled up by the outlier (100).
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates all three averages on paper and explains which is most representative for a given data set

stages.description: Finding median and mode mentally for small data sets, choosing the most appropriate average for context, and explaining why outliers affect the mean more than the median
stages.example_activity: Shoe sizes in a class: 4, 4, 5, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 7. Median? Mode? Mean? Which is most useful for a shoe shop? House prices: £150k, £160k, £170k, £180k, £850k. Which average should a newspaper report? Why?
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the appropriate average for any context and explains the impact of outliers on each measure

stages.description: Building bar charts, pie charts and line graphs from real data using physical materials (cubes for bars, fraction circles for pie charts, string for line graphs on wall charts)
stages.example_activity: Collect class data on travel to school. Build a bar chart with cubes. Build a pie chart with fraction circle sectors. Which shows proportions better? Plot temperature data on a wall chart with sticky dots and connect with string. Which shows change over time?
stages.transition_cue: Child explains which chart type suits which data: bar charts for comparing categories, pie charts for proportions, line graphs for change over time

stages.description: Constructing all chart types on paper with correct labels, scales and titles, interpreting charts to answer questions, and identifying misleading features
stages.example_activity: Construct a pie chart and a bar chart for the same data. Answer questions from each. Look at a graph with a truncated y-axis: does it exaggerate differences? Redraw with the y-axis starting at 0. Choose the best chart type for: (a) survey results, (b) temperature over a week, (c) budget breakdown.
stages.transition_cue: Child constructs any chart type correctly, selects the most appropriate type for a purpose, and identifies when a graph is misleading

stages.description: Interpreting charts from descriptions, evaluating chart choice critically, and solving problems requiring extraction of data from multiple representations
stages.example_activity: A pie chart shows 25% sport, 40% music, 35% reading for 200 pupils. How many chose music? A line graph shows sales rising then falling. When were sales highest? A newspaper uses a pie chart with 12 categories. Is this a good choice? Suggest a better one.
stages.transition_cue: Child interprets any statistical representation, selects the best chart type for any purpose, and evaluates charts critically

stages.description: Using times table grids, fraction-decimal-percentage cards and place value equipment for rapid fact retrieval practice, building speed through concrete manipulation
stages.example_activity: Complete a blank 12×12 grid as fast as you can while staying accurate. Match all FDP cards: 3/4 → 0.75 → 75%. Quick-fire place value: show 3,456 with counters, now show 10 times as much. Use number bond cards: 0.7 + ? = 1.
stages.transition_cue: Child recalls all times tables, key equivalences and number bonds without any reference materials, selecting efficient calculation strategies

stages.description: Completing timed mixed-fact retrieval exercises on paper, selecting mental vs written methods for different calculations, and recording strategy choices
stages.example_activity: Mixed exercise: 7×8, 1/4 of 60, 35% of 200, 4.7+3.8, 1000−387. For each, write whether you used mental or written method and why. Calculate 4,998 + 2,003 — mental (adjust: 5,000 + 2,001) or written? Which is faster?
stages.transition_cue: Child demonstrates fluent fact recall and strategic method selection in timed exercises with high accuracy

stages.description: Applying number fluency within complex problem-solving: rapid fact recall freeing working memory for higher-level reasoning
stages.example_activity: In your head: 25 × 16 (use 25×4×4 = 400). What is 12.5% of 80? (Half of 25% = half of 20 = 10.) Estimate 487 × 23 ÷ 9 before calculating. Solve: a number multiplied by itself gives 144. What is it?
stages.transition_cue: Child applies number facts instantly within multi-step problems, with working memory free for reasoning and problem structure

stages.description: Using physical examples and counter-examples to test conjectures: building arrays, sorting shapes, or testing number properties with real objects
stages.example_activity: Conjecture: 'Multiplying two numbers always makes a bigger number.' Test with counters: 3 × 4 = 12 (bigger). 1 × 5 = 5 (same). 0 × 7 = 0 (smaller). Counter-example found! Refine: 'Multiplying two numbers greater than 1 always gives a bigger result.' Test again.
stages.transition_cue: Child tests conjectures systematically using examples and counter-examples and refines statements based on findings

stages.description: Recording mathematical arguments on paper: writing 'if...then' statements, drawing diagrams to support reasoning, and using algebraic notation to express general rules
stages.example_activity: 'Always, Sometimes, Never: The sum of two odd numbers is even.' Test: 3+5=8 ✓, 7+9=16 ✓, 1+1=2 ✓. Always true. Write why: odd + odd = (2a+1)+(2b+1) = 2a+2b+2 = 2(a+b+1), which is even. Draw a diagram showing two odd numbers as pairs-plus-one, and how the two leftover ones pair up.
stages.transition_cue: Child writes mathematical justifications that explain WHY something must be true, not just that it IS true in specific cases

stages.description: Constructing and communicating mathematical arguments using precise language, generalising from patterns, and distinguishing between examples and proof
stages.example_activity: Prove that the sum of three consecutive numbers is always divisible by 3. (n + n+1 + n+2 = 3n+3 = 3(n+1).) Is it true that all prime numbers are odd? Construct a counter-example. Explain the difference between 'I checked 5 cases and it worked' and 'I proved it must always work'.
stages.transition_cue: Child constructs logical arguments using algebraic reasoning and clearly distinguishes between demonstration and proof

stages.description: Using physical manipulatives to model problems: building with blocks, drawing diagrams with real objects, acting out scenarios, and working systematically with concrete materials
stages.example_activity: A farmer has chickens and cows. She counts 20 heads and 56 legs. Use counters: start with 20 chickens (40 legs). Swap chickens for cows one at a time (each swap adds 2 legs): need 8 swaps to reach 56 legs. So 8 cows, 12 chickens. Did you work systematically?
stages.transition_cue: Child selects an appropriate strategy (draw a diagram, work systematically, try simpler cases, work backwards) and explains their choice

stages.description: Drawing diagrams (bar models, tables, number lines) to represent problems, recording systematic trials, and evaluating which strategy is most efficient
stages.example_activity: Problem: I think of a number, double it, add 5 and get 23. Draw a bar model to work backwards: 23 − 5 = 18, 18 ÷ 2 = 9. The number is 9. Problem: How many ways can you make 20p using only 2p, 5p and 10p coins? Use a systematic table to list all possibilities.
stages.transition_cue: Child represents problems pictorially, selects efficient strategies, and verifies answers for reasonableness

stages.description: Solving unfamiliar multi-step problems using named strategies, checking answers, and reflecting on strategy choice
stages.example_activity: A swimming pool fills in 6 hours and empties in 10 hours. If both taps are open, how long to fill? (Think about the rate: 1/6 − 1/10 = 5/30 − 3/30 = 2/30 = 1/15 per hour. 15 hours.) Describe your strategy. Was there a more efficient approach?
stages.transition_cue: Child approaches unfamiliar problems with confidence, articulates their strategy before starting, checks answers, and reflects on efficiency
